I cannot believe that this L.Ron Hubbard type of interplanetary nonsense hasn’t been debunked yet.  But I’m happy to do that right now.  Our own Earth was found to have surprisingly large amounts of xenon-129 in the atmosphere, and that is xenon-129 which we know pre-dates nuclear weapons due to isotopic aging calculations.  Originally we believed that this xenon occurred as a result of Iodine decay - yes that’s right, xenon-129 does not only occur from nuclear weapons detonations, it is created by simple Iodine decay.  What scientists finally discovered however is that the chemical and aging profile of our atmospheric xenon-129 exactly matched that found in comet samples - the xenon-129 traveled here as a component of comets and it was released when they burned up in the atmosphere.  And guess what - that’s where the Martian xenon-129 came from as well - comet impacts and breakups.  End of alien nuclear war theory.

Xenon is relatively rare in the Sun's atmosphere, on Earth, and in the asteroids and comets. The atmosphere of Mars shows a similar xenon abundance to that of Earth: 0.08 parts per million.[39] However, Mars shows a higher proportion of 129Xe than the Earth or the Sun. As this isotope is generated by radioactive decay, the result may indicate that Mars lost most of its primordial atmosphere, possibly within the first 100 million years after the planet was formed.

The abundance of XE-129 in Martian soils is the result of the XE gas settling out of the atmosphere as the the atmosphere escaped into space.

"The isotopes -- variants that have different numbers of neutrons -- are formed in the loose rocks and material that make up the regolith -- the surface layer down to solid rock. The chemistry begins when cosmic rays penetrate into the surface material. If the cosmic rays strike an atom of barium (Ba), the barium can lose one or more of its neutrons (n0). Atoms of xenon can pick up some of those neutrons – a process called neutron capture – to form the isotopes xenon-124 and xenon-126. In the same way, atoms of bromine (Br) can lose some of their neutrons to krypton, leading to the formation of krypton-80 and krypton-82 isotopes. These isotopes can enter the atmosphere when the regolith is disturbed by impacts and abrasion, allowing gas to escape."

Source: NASA
